review.title: Dispute Resolution Using Argumentation-Based Mediation
review.abstract: Mediation is a process, in which both parties agree to resolve their dispute by negotiating over alternative solutions presented by a mediator. In order to construct such solutions, mediation brings more information and knowledge, and, if possible, resources to the negotiation table. The contribution of this paper is the automated mediation machinery which does that. It presents an argumentation-based mediation approach that extends the logic-based approach to argumentation-based negotiation involving BDI agents. The paper describes the mediation algorithm. For comparison it illustrates the method with a case study used in an earlier work. It demonstrates how the computational mediator can deal with realistic situations in which the negotiating agents would otherwise fail due to lack of knowledge and/or resources.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction and Motivation
sections.text: Dispute resolution is a complex process, depending on the willingness of the parties involved to reach a consensus when they are satisfied with the outcome of the negotiations, enabling them to achieve part or all of their objectives with the resources available. In many cases, such a negotiation depends on the search for alternative solutions, which requires in-depth knowledge of the subject matter at issue for sound reasoning; such information may not be available to the negotiating parties and negotiations may fail. Mediation, a less radical alternative to mediation, can help both parties reach an amicable agreement. [1] This paper presents an argument-based mediation system that builds on previous work in the area of argument-based negotiation. It is an extension of the work presented in [1] and focuses on issues where negotiations have stalled and had no solution. [1] Agents contain all the knowledge and resources needed to resolve their dispute - a relatively strong assumption in the context of real negotiations based on mediation.

sections.heading: 3 Agent Architecture
sections.text: The ABN system presented in [1] deals with BDI agents in a multi-context framework that defines different theoretical components, links them together, and easily transforms them into executable components. [1] The authors use different contexts to represent different components of an agent architecture, and specify the interactions between them using the bridge rules between contexts. We briefly recall the components of the agent architecture within the ABN system [1] and add a new "resource" component for mediation purposes. Units are structural units that represent the main components of the architecture. There are four units within a multi-context BDI agent, namely: the communication unit and units for each of the beliefs, desires, and intentions. Bridge rules connect units that specify the internal agent architecture by determining their relationship. Three well-established groups of relationships for BDI agents have been identified in [30]: strong realism, weak realism, and realism.

sections.heading: 4 Mediation Algorithm
sections.text: In a mediation process, both parties try to resolve their dispute by negotiating alternative solutions presented by a mediator. sections.text: Our automatic mediation system uses the ABN system proposed in [1], which is based on the one proposed in [24]. The system constructs a series of logical steps (arguments) for and against statements of interest and can be considered an extension of classical logic. sections.text: Compared to Parsons et al. [1], our agents do not have all the knowledge and resources to resolve their dispute; therefore, the classic argument fails. The mediation algorithm runs in two successive rounds and ends with: 1. Success if both agents accept the solution proposed by the mediator; 2. sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: Mediation brings more information and knowledge to the negotiating table, so an automated mediator would need the machinery to do so. To solve this problem in an automated environment, we have presented an ABN approach that extends ABN's logical approach with BDI agents, as outlined in [1]. We have introduced a mediator into the multi-agent architecture that has extensive knowledge of mediation cases and access to resources, and the mediator proposes solutions that will become the subject of further negotiations if the conflicting parties cannot resolve the conflict on their own. We have described our mediation algorithm and illustrated it using the same case study presented in [1]. The presence of a mediator in ABN enables us to deal with realistic situations when negotiations stall. In this work, we assumed that the actors and the mediator operate within the same ontology and describe the negotiation area. In the real world, negotiators may interpret the same term differently.
